author: Alistair Anderson
title: Labour law trims Adcorp earnings | Management
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles Adcorp: Spreading its wings, and not a moment too soon Adcorp’s bold strategy reaps R13bn reward Related multimedia WATCH: Stock Watch pick — Adcorp and Life Healthcare In this article JSE-listed companies: Adcorp ADR View company tearsheet RECRUITMENT firm Adcorp’s performance in the six months to August was dulled by clients’ reactions to new labour legislation, with various companies taking on permanent staff or ending contracts all together.
Headline earnings per share of 125.2c were achieved in the reporting period, 17% lower than 150.9c per share for the comparative prior period. Diluted headline earnings per share dropped 15.4% to 120.7c per share from 142.7c per share.
"The passing of the new Labour Relations Act initially led to a high degree of uncertainty in the South African market resulting in a knee jerk reaction from a number of prominent clients," the group said.
CEO Richard Pike said the group had lost some clients locally, but international assets had softened the blow.
"Our volumes fell quite a bit. These past six months have been very difficult. A significant number of contract staff were either taken on as permanent employees of our clients or simply had their contracts of employment terminated.
"While we won’t get local volumes back in the second half of the 2016 financial year, I believe the market will stabilise."
Mr Pike said SA remained a key and important market for the group given the scale advantage it offered. There were many market opportunities that still persisted despite a sluggish employment market, he said.
Adcorp was planning a $100m capital raise in the near future for acquisitions.
